messages.text:
Not having frequent automerges is really frustrating.
Because if you are waiting for a release, to e.g. make a follow up release on a downstream package, or to tell a users that opened an issue "it is now fixed and releases", then waiting >10 minutes really messed with the flow of your day.
Especially if it's the last thing you want to do before you finish work.
You don't really want to leave these things for the next day since you're livable to forget things.
Just in general context switching sucks.
Having to come back to a thing much later requires context switching

elements.text:

Especially if it's the last thing you want to do before you finish work.
You don't really want to leave these things for the next day since you're livable to forget things.

messages.text: If we want to reliably run AutoMerge every 10 minutes, we can probably just set up a Serverless `schedule` event on Lambda. The Lambda function would just use the GitHub API to trigger a workflow dispatch event (<https://docs.github.com/en/free-pro-team@latest/rest/reference/actions#create-a-workflow-dispatch-event>).

schedule
event on Lambda. The Lambda function would just use the GitHub API to trigger a workflow dispatch event (

It's a random delay between 0 and 20 minutes

messages.text: Perhaps we can have a Pkg call to discuss the idea of instant-merging. Personally I'm not a fan, but let's see what others think.

elements.text: Perhaps we can have a Pkg call to discuss the idea of instant-merging. Personally I'm not a fan, but let's see what others think.

messages.text: While I think it is a bit useful to have a delay, I think if I had to make a choice between what we have now and having things reliably instantly merged when CI passes I would absolutely chose the later

elements.text: While I think it is a bit useful to have a delay, I think if I had to make a choice between what we have now and having things reliably instantly merged when CI passes I would absolutely chose the later

workflow_dispatch

messages.text: It's a bunch of work to set up, and maintain

elements.text: It's a bunch of work to set up, and maintain

messages.text: What if, instead of instant-merging, we just ran the "AutoMerge.cron" code path at the end of every AutoMerge PR job.

elements.text: What if, instead of instant-merging, we just ran the "AutoMerge.cron" code path at the end of every AutoMerge PR job.

messages.text: It would look like this:

elements.text: It would look like this:

messages.text: Person A makes a registration for PkgA.jl. AutoMerge runs a PR job on PkgA.jl. At the end of that job, it also runs the "cron" code path. This does not merge PkgA (since it has not been open for the minimum period), but it merges all PRs that have been open for the minimum period).

elements.text: Person A makes a registration for PkgA.jl. AutoMerge runs a PR job on PkgA.jl. At the end of that job, it also runs the "cron" code path. This does not merge PkgA (since it has not been open for the minimum period), but it merges all PRs that have been open for the minimum period).

messages.text: 20 minutes later, Person B makes a registration for PkgB.jl. AutoMerge runs a PR job on PkgA.jl. At the end of that job, when it runs the "cron" code path, the PR for PkgA.jl is now merged b/c it has been open for the minimum period.

elements.text: 20 minutes later, Person B makes a registration for PkgB.jl. AutoMerge runs a PR job on PkgA.jl. At the end of that job, when it runs the "cron" code path, the PR for PkgA.jl is now merged b/c it has been open for the minimum period.

messages.text:
Now the obvious question: what if nobody opens a PR after person B, and the PkgB.jl PR is waiting, and it has been 40 minutes and GitHub still hasn't opened a cron job.

Simple: simply close and re-open the PkgB.jl PR. After the PR job passes on the PkgB.jl PR, since it has been open for the minimum period, it will instantly be merged.

elements.text:
Now the obvious question: what if nobody opens a PR after person B, and the PkgB.jl PR is waiting, and it has been 40 minutes and GitHub still hasn't opened a cron job.

Simple: simply close and re-open the PkgB.jl PR. After the PR job passes on the PkgB.jl PR, since it has been open for the minimum period, it will instantly be merged.

messages.text: This will add on average an additional 2-3 minutes to each PR job, but with the result of faster merges.

elements.text: This will add on average an additional 2-3 minutes to each PR job, but with the result of faster merges.

messages.text: By faster, I mean closer to the "floor" (minimum waiting period)

elements.text: By faster, I mean closer to the "floor" (minimum waiting period)

elements.text: Let's see what some of the other maintainers think.

messages.text: sorry for coming late to the part, but: what exactly is the problem with instant merges?

elements.text: sorry for coming late to the part, but: what exactly is the problem with instant merges?

messages.text:
The first draft of AutoMerge actually did instant merge new versions.

During Pkg calls, we became concerned that this would cause a problem when people made a mistake in their registration, and suddenly didn't have a chance to fix the mistake before it was instant-merged.

So we added the delay.

elements.text:
The first draft of AutoMerge actually did instant merge new versions.

During Pkg calls, we became concerned that this would cause a problem when people made a mistake in their registration, and suddenly didn't have a chance to fix the mistake before it was instant-merged.

So we added the delay.

messages.text: could this then also be resolved by letting the action which runs the automerge test simply sleep for, say, 5 minutes ? Or 5 times 1 minute, with some printing in between?

elements.text: could this then also be resolved by letting the action which runs the automerge test simply sleep for, say, 5 minutes ? Or 5 times 1 minute, with some printing in between?

messages.text: (or 20 minutes, or whatever) ?

elements.text: (or 20 minutes, or whatever) ?

messages.text: There's an organization-wide cap on concurrent GHA jobs. 20, I believe. So if a PR job is sleeping (but still running), it counts towards the cap

elements.text: There's an organization-wide cap on concurrent GHA jobs. 20, I believe. So if a PR job is sleeping (but still running), it counts towards the cap

messages.text: I also thought that, but they'd keep the queue occupied

elements.text: I also thought that, but they'd keep the queue occupied

messages.text: And thus the queue builds up

elements.text: And thus the queue builds up

messages.text: also, we can't keep a job sleeping for 3 days

elements.text: also, we can't keep a job sleeping for 3 days

messages.text: So for new packages, we are going to stick with the current system regardless, right? It's fine to wait for the cron job to merge new packages- the waiting period is 3 days, so I think it's fine to have it open a couple extra hours

elements.text: So for new packages, we are going to stick with the current system regardless, right? It's fine to wait for the cron job to merge new packages- the waiting period is 3 days, so I think it's fine to have it open a couple extra hours

messages.text: It's only for new versions that we have this question of instant merging

elements.text: It's only for new versions that we have this question of instant merging

messages.text: It's a lot more work but the obvious alternative to having fast automerge so a sequence of dependent registrations can happen in a timely manner is to make it possible for all of those registrations to go together.

elements.text: It's a lot more work but the obvious alternative to having fast automerge so a sequence of dependent registrations can happen in a timely manner is to make it possible for all of those registrations to go together.

messages.text: Would there be any problem bumping RegistryCI Julia compat to 1.5 in order to get hold of 1.5 features?

elements.text: Would there be any problem bumping RegistryCI Julia compat to 1.5 in order to get hold of 1.5 features?

messages.text:
> I really think it's important that we have some delay before AutoMerging a PR. It's not uncommon for someone to realize a mistake is made
You can setup a timer that doesn't block the queue with the new GitHub environments/deploy restrictions. (not sure how reliable in regards to time that is yet) I'm guessing that GH's own automerge request thing will eventually make its way into the API too. Both combined would allow for a reliable on-PR automerge.

elements.text: I really think it's important that we have some delay before AutoMerging a PR. It's not uncommon for someone to realize a mistake is made

messages.text: the stopwatch seems to work: <https://github.com/JuliaRegistries/General/pull/27287>  but my understanding is that we aren't running the automerge yet?

elements.text: the stopwatch seems to work:
but my understanding is that we aren't running the automerge yet?

messages.text: it's nice because it shows the countdown live

elements.text: it's nice because it shows the countdown live

messages.text: Yeah I'll finish it up later this week

elements.text: Yeah I'll finish it up later this week

messages.text: Basically we'll trigger a new cron job after the stopwatch runs out. But we'll first check when the last cron job was. And we'll only create a new cron job if the last cron job was more than 15 minutes ago

elements.text: Basically we'll trigger a new cron job after the stopwatch runs out. But we'll first check when the last cron job was. And we'll only create a new cron job if the last cron job was more than 15 minutes ago

messages.text: I just realized: not only can we run the stopwatch on PR jobs

elements.text: I just realized: not only can we run the stopwatch on PR jobs

messages.text: But we can run it on cron jobs!

elements.text: But we can run it on cron jobs!

messages.text: So, after one cron job finishes, we can start a 20 minute stopwatch, and when the stopwatch finishes, we can use a personal access token to manually trigger another "cron" job

elements.text: So, after one cron job finishes, we can start a 20 minute stopwatch, and when the stopwatch finishes, we can use a personal access token to manually trigger another "cron" job

messages.text: Thus ensuring that we have jobs every 20 minutes

elements.text: Thus ensuring that we have jobs every 20 minutes

messages.text: This is all assuming that the scheduling for environment "wait timers" is more reliable than the scheduling for cron jobs

elements.text: This is all assuming that the scheduling for environment "wait timers" is more reliable than the scheduling for cron jobs
